newsitem.title: USA: Conrail says no sale to Norfolk Southern.
newsitem.headline: Conrail says no sale to Norfolk Southern.

text.p: Conrail Inc. insisted Friday it would not be sold to hostile bidder Norfolk Southern Corp., and Conrail Chairman David LeVan said the railroad was committed to its proposed $9.3 billion merger with CSX Corp.
In remarks prepared for delivery to a Conrail shareholders meeting slated to start at noon EST, LeVan urged investors to back the CSX deal.
"The Conrail board has determined that a sale to Norfolk Southern is not in the best interests of Conrail, and the Conrail board will not agree to a sale to Norfolk Southern," he said.
LeVan also said Conrail's board would not be swayed by a proposal by Norfolk Southern to buy 9.9 percent of the company if shareholders defeated a measure that is critical to the CSX union.
"This promise is a stop-gap effort designed to entice shareholders to vote 'no' today and to shake the resolve of the Conrail board. That resolve will not be shaken," he said.
Conrail has repeatedly rejected Norfolk Southern's $10.3 billion bid, saying that CSX's offer provides more benefits.

"I hope you all understand the Conrail board is fully committed to the CSX-Conrail merger and, regardless of speculation to the contrary, there can be no transaction with Norfolk Southern until 1999 at the earliest," he said.
The proposed merger pact between Conrail and CSX prohibits either party, should their pact fail, from merging with another company until 1999.
The vote was expected to be very close.
Conrail's stock gained 25 cents to $103.75, CSX was up $1.75 to $46.75, and Norfolk Southern was unchanged at $88.125 in midday trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
